news.title: At First-Ever MAHA Summit, JD Vance Presses the Need for People, 'Willing to Challenge Orthodoxy'
news.text:
KENNEDY: Well, you had a vice president like Dick Cheney, who seemed to be actually running the country. And you had these relationships...

[Audience breaks into laughter]

VANCE: Not very well as it turns out.

KENNEDY (cont'd) ...Al Gore and Bill Clinton and Mondale and Carter who had close personal friendships. You have an amazing job because you have a president who clearly puts tremendous faith in you, he relies on you, he's given you an extraordinary retinue of responsibilities. Talk a little bit about how your relationship with the president has evolved.

VANCE: Yeah, That's a great question...

KENNEDY: It's clear to all of us in the cabinet, how much affection that he has for you, and how much he relies on your wisdom.

VANCE: It's interesting, you're exactly right. The job of the vice president is incredibly contingent on the president that you're serving under. And you can have a president who effectively just passes off big swaths of responsibility. You can have a president who delegates, you can have a president who has no trust in their vice president: Kamala Harris [audience laughs], so, it doesn't go very well for that particular vice president.

But, I think there are two ways that I try to think of my job with the President of the United States. Number one, he requires honest counsel. In other words, if I have an opinion about something, whether I agree or disagree with the administrative position, it's really, really important that I talk to the president about it. He doesn't want Yes men, and I think that's one of the reasons why you guys have a great relationship because you're always thinking about how can I actually give the president the best counsel.

But then, the second thing is, when the president makes a decision, it's your job to execute. It's not to run to the papers and say, "Well, actually, I disagreed with this decision," or run to the Congress and badmouth the administration, it's to execute.

And I think the reason why the president has trust in me, Is because, yes, I absolutely tell the president what I think about a given issue. But I also recognize, I'm the vice president, he's the president, and when the President of the United States makes the decision, it's time to go and get it done. In part because I get things done. Right? Sometimes Congress doesn't cooperate, sometimes the private sector doesn't cooperate, Like, I'm not saying any of us have a batting average of 1000. 

But what I think all of us who have earned the president's trust do, is that when the administration makes a decision, when he makes a decision, we actually go out and get it done. And that's why this job has been so empowering for me is that the president trusts me, he knows I'm going to give him honest counsel, he knows that if he asks me to get something done, I'm going to try my best to actually go and do it. And that's why whe have a good partnership, I think that's why the administration has been so effective this time around, is because there's a lot of people with a very wide diversity of opinions, but we get out there and we try to do the best job for the American people and the President of the United States. And because of that, there's a lot of trust and a lot of affection in the cabinet.

I mean, you've seen this, I've seen this. But when we're sitting in there, and the cameras are off, and we're just talking about an issue, there is a deep level of affection and trust between all the senior members of the team. I don't know how it's possible to do this job without it, but I know it's why we've been so successful in the past 10 months.
news.author: Jennifer Oliver O'connell

news.title: The Epstein email receipts show sex offender‚Äôs deep reach in Washington went far beyond Trump
news.text:
The former prince, Andrew Mountbatten Windsor, fell into disgrace after it was revealed that he kept in contact with Jeffrey Epstein after the financier was convicted of sex crimes in 2008 in a ‚Äúsweetheart deal‚Äù that largely allowed him to escape judgment for his crimes.

But were Washington‚Äôs elite held to those same standards, there would be plenty of disgrace to go around.

On Wednesday, another trove of email chains involving Jeffrey Epstein and his former girlfriend, Ghislaine Maxwell, was released by the House Oversight Committee‚Äôs members, which include both Republicans and Democrats. The emails revealed startling insinuations about Donald Trump himself, including one where he wrote to a biographer that Trump ‚Äúknew about the girls‚Äù. The White House and Trump have strongly denied that the president knew about any illegal activity.

The emails released on Wednesday also centered a second spotlight on Epstein‚Äôs other associates, however, and some illustrate clearly the wide range of the alleged sex trafficker and convicted pedophile‚Äôs connections to America‚Äôs political establishment, in several cases after his public reputation was already sullied by a conviction for soliciting an underage girl for prostitution.

They included messages to two men who have been key figures in both the pre-Trump and post-Trump D.C. political world: Larry Summers, former secretary of the Treasury under Bill Clinton and director of the National Economic Council under Barack Obama, and Steve Bannon. Once a White House official in Trump‚Äôs first term and formerly head of Breitbart News, Bannon remains a spiritual leader of the populist MAGA right through his War Room podcast and retains a grip on a large portion of the Trump-aligned voter base.

Epstein‚Äôs reach didn‚Äôt stop there, of course.

It extended to friendly emails with Michael Wolff, the well-connected D.C. journalist and biographer whose books about Donald Trump have invoked the president‚Äôs fury. It extended to Reid Hoffman, a Democratic megadonor and tech CEO who co-founded LinkedIn and most recently supported both Joe Biden and, later, Kamala Harris‚Äôs 2024 campaigns for the presidency. In 2016, he was chatting with Noam Chomsky, often considered a luminary of American left-leaning anti-corporatist political thought. He also had conversations with Doug Band, a key member of Bill and Hillary Clinton‚Äôs inner circle, though Band‚Äôs conversations seem to have stopped before Epstein‚Äôs conviction.

There‚Äôs the foreign angle, too: In 2013, Epstein was emailing with Israel‚Äôs then-defence minister, Ehud Barak, according to emails obtained by Drop Site News. The two met in Manhattan, at Epstein‚Äôs home, one month after Barak left the government, and the news outlet reported that an extensive backchannel existed between Epstein and Barak‚Äôs personal email account during the latter‚Äôs time in government. Drop Site has reported those emails continued all the way through the mid-2010s, as Epstein attempted to use his influence to broker a meeting between Barak and Vladimir Putin aimed at halting the conflict in Syria.

Inconsistent as the political leanings of his friends were, there was one thread that remained true throughout: Epstein‚Äôs attraction to political power. His energetic networking with mid-to-high-profile political figures suggests that the billionaire sex criminal cared most about maintaining a connection to whichever factions were dominant or at least carried importance in Washington.

He emailed with a former Obama White House counsel during the last year of the 44th president‚Äôs term. His conversations with Bannon took place in 2018, one year after Bannon was unceremoniously ousted from the White House by John Kelly. Summers, who emailed Epstein his detailed thoughts about Trump‚Äôs political strength in 2017, was still a leading voice heading into Joe Biden‚Äôs presidency, which began in 2021.

Apart from Band, who cut contact with Epstein earlier, there‚Äôs little sign of any enmity towards a man who was credibly accused of running a sex trafficking ring involving girls as young as 12. Bannon, who corresponded with Epstein in 2018, appeared to be aligned with the billionaire as he wrote that together they could build a populist, nationalist conservative coalition that would ‚Äústaves [sic] off Time‚Äôs Up for a decade‚Äù ‚Äî a revealing look at their thoughts on a movement aimed at exposing men who used positions of power to cover up sexual crimes and misconduct. Summers‚Äôs emails to Epstein read as private opinions and off-color thoughts shared only among close friends.

‚ÄúI observed that half of the IQ in the world was possessed by women,‚Äù wrote Summers in October of 2017, ‚Äúwithout mentioning that they are more than 51 percent of the population...‚Äù

‚ÄúDO NOT REPEAT THIS INSIGHT,‚Äù that email concluded.

In reality, the emails confirm a long-held suspicion for many Americans: In D.C., like Hollywood and the media industry, ‚Äúdisgrace‚Äù often lasts only as long as the public‚Äôs attention span. Why else would so many powerful men be corresponding with a man accused of heinous crimes that have now enveloped much of the American right and left in a fervor to expose?

The answer may be simply that they never expected that attention to amount to anything serious, and likely thought that the American justice system‚Äôs penchant for protecting the powerful would rise to the occasion again.
news.author: John Bowden

news.summary: Emails to political luminaries and D.C. mainstays makes clear: Epstein‚Äôs influence crossed the breadth of Washington‚Äôs political spectrum, writes John Bowden
news.author: John Bowden

news.title: Study shows bail reform failed, Trump family‚Äôs bitcoin reek and other commentary
news.text:
Crime beat: Study Shows Bail Reform Failed

A new analysis of New York‚Äôs bail reforms from John Jay College‚Äôs Data Collaborative for Justice does the opposite of what the researches claim, explains City Journal‚Äôs Rafael A. Mangual: It confirms ‚Äúwhat bail-reform critics have been saying all along‚Äù ‚Äî that ‚Äúit was a bad idea‚Äù to ‚Äúrestrict bail while prohibiting judges from detaining dangerous pretrial defendants based on public safety risk.‚Äù Notably, when it comes to ‚Äúhigh-risk‚Äù defendants, the ‚Äúreduced use of bail‚Äù is linked to worse outcomes, including ‚Äúhigher arrest rates in general and for violent felonies in particular.‚Äù The findings ‚Äúpoint in the same direction‚Äù as the researchers‚Äô earlier analyses. But: ‚ÄúWill the politicians in Albany considering changes to bail policy be guided by evidence ‚Äî or ideology?‚Äù

Liberal: Trump Family‚Äôs Bitcoin Reek

Cryptocurrency ‚Äúhas been spectacularly good for the Trumps,‚Äù reports The Free Press‚Äô Joe Nocera, but oy, the ethical cloud! ‚ÄúWere [Donald] Trump not president, it is hard to imagine that there would have been much demand for any of Trump‚Äôs tokens,‚Äù but ‚Äúmeme coin sales generated $320 million in fees for the Trumps, as well as untold millions in the meme coins that the Trumps still hold.‚Äù Worse, in at least three cases, ‚Äúpeople who helped enrich Trump and his family through the use of cryptocurrencies were looking for something from the administration‚Äù ‚Äî and soon ‚Äúgot what they wanted.‚Äù One crypto billionaire who‚Äôd fled the country in 2023 after the Securities and Exchange Commission charged him ‚Äúwith manipulating the cryptocurrency market,‚Äù saw the SEC pause its case against him ‚Äî seemingly indefinitely. Another crypto billionaire won a presidential pardon after a terrorism-linked money-laundering conviction. And the UAE won an OK to buy ‚Äúadvanced semiconductor chips‚Äîdespite fears among national security experts that the UAE would give access to the chips to China.‚Äù

Conservative: Josh Shapiro‚Äôs Tough Choice

Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro, was ‚Äúthe obvious choice on paper‚Äù to be Kamala Harris‚Äôs veep choice last year, notes Commentary‚Äôs Seth Mandel, but his ‚Äúvisible and proud Jewishness‚Äù made him an ‚Äúuntenable option‚Äù for the party‚Äôs base after ‚ÄúGaza became the litmus test for progressive political activist groups.‚Äù He‚Äôs a ‚Äúswing-state moderate‚Äù who wins elections, but the ‚Äúprogressive base would rather lose than win with him.‚Äù He could win ‚Äúa place in the party elite in return for a public apology for his Jewishness,‚Äù or at least if he learns ‚Äúto keep mum unless he has an anti-Zionist-ish thing to say.‚Äù Will Shapiro ‚Äúresist this quiet capitulation‚Äù?

From the right: ‚ÄòChoose Country Over Party‚Äô

Sen. John Fetterman (D-Pa.) ‚Äúhasn‚Äôt just talked about opposing the shutdown ‚Äî he has acted,‚Äù cheers the Washington Examiner‚Äôs Salena Zito, casting ‚Äú15 votes in favor of reopening the government‚Äù while fellow Dems ‚Äúvoted against 15 times.‚Äù He calls his party‚Äôs shutdown strategy a ‚Äúfailure‚Äù because the deal now ‚Äúagreed to is the exact same one that was on the table 40 days ago.‚Äù ‚ÄúSome Pennsylvania Democrats were already plotting to challenge him in a 2028 primary,‚Äù but ‚ÄúFetterman has never been a favorite of his party‚Äôs establishment‚Äù: He wins because ‚Äúvoters have consistently stood by him.‚Äù

Campus watch: Rise of a Pro-Speech University

‚ÄúToo many campuses seem committed to teaching their students what to think ‚Äî not how to think,‚Äù but ‚Äúa start-up university in Texas is showing that there is another path forward,‚Äù and it‚Äôs attracting attention, applauds USA Today‚Äôs Ingrid Jacques. Co-founded by The Free Press‚Äô Bari Weiss, the University of Austin doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúcharge students tuition and does not accept government funding, relying instead on private donations.‚Äù And it just got a big one: Billionaire Jeff Yass ‚Äúis donating $100 million.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe same independence, curiosity and diversity of views‚Äù Weiss ‚Äúbrought to the news media are echoed‚Äù at UATX. While ‚Äúthe country‚Äôs historically esteemed colleges have some of the worst rankings for free speech,‚Äù ‚ÄúUATX wants the opposite for its students, who should not expect to be coddled.‚Äù 

‚Äî Compiled by The Post Editorial Board
news.summary: A new analysis of New York‚Äôs bail reforms from John Jay College‚Äôs Data Collaborative for Justice does the opposite of what the researches claim, explains City Journal‚Äôs Rafael A. Mangual.
news.author: Post Editorial Board

news.title: Irony: ‚ÄòNo Kings‚Äô Dems Try Desperately to Revive Kennedy Dynasty ‚Ä¶ Again
news.text:
Seeing a lot of videos like this with people shocked at how white the No Kings was - well it's basically the audience that watches MSNBC. pic.twitter.com/2TDjVyGJPP‚Äî Sasha Stone (@realsashastone) October 20, 2025

Aaaand shot:

At the Ann Arbor "No Kings" protest, a far-left anarchist contingent handed out these flyers threatening that if their demands are not met‚Äîthe dismantling of ICE, Homeland Security, law enforcement, the Supreme Court, and property rights‚Äîthey will escalate their attacks and‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/mxgKYwLmU3‚Äî Andy Ngo (@MrAndyNgo) October 21, 2025

Aaaaaaand shot:

The "No Kings" rally isn‚Äôt protesting Trump but rather the agenda the majority of America voted for. The Left isn't protesting a king but their fellow Americans. They aren‚Äôt standing up for democracy ‚Äî they are protesting against it. My opening monologue on "BATYA!" @NewsNation: pic.twitter.com/dvSs9djCCS‚Äî Batya Ungar-Sargon (@bungarsargon) October 19, 2025

Jack Schlossberg, grandson of former U.S. President John F. Kennedy, announced he will run for Congress next year.In a social media post late Tuesday, Schlossberg said he would be seeking the Democratic nomination to replace longtime Rep. Jerry Nadler in New York‚Äôs 12th Congressional District. Nadler, a leading liberal figure for the Democratic Party in Congress, said in September that he would not seek reelection. ...Schlossberg is the son of Caroline Kennedy and Edwin Schlossberg, and the nephew of the late John F. Kennedy Jr. He worked as a political correspondent for Vogue during the 2024 election, and he became a New York delegate to the Democratic National Convention after Kamala Harris replaced then-president Joe Biden as the Democratic nominee.However, he is particularly well known as a social media personality with more than 1.5 million followers across TikTok and Instagram. He posts clips of himself singing the Beatles without a shirt on, reciting Lord Byron while riding a RipStik skateboard, or making political commentary.

The most amusing irony about this is the rejection of Robert Kennedy Jr by Democrats, both in the presidential primary when challenging a senile Joe Biden, and then even more vociferously after RFK Jr endorsed and campaigned for Trump. Schlossberg himself was particularly vocal in shunning his cousin. Some Kennedys are more equal than others, apparently.

At least the latest remake of Dynasty: Camelot stars an actual Kennedy this time. A few years ago, Robert Francis O'Rourke got the Kennedy treatment when he challenged Ted Cruz for the Senate in 2018, and then tossed his hat in the ring for the 2020 presidential primaries. O'Rourke flopped out of that contest (as did Kamala Harris), and then went on to get shellacked by Greg Abbott in the 2022 Texas gubernatorial election. Supposedly, O'Rourke plans another run at the Senate next year, but Beto won't get the Annie Leibovitz treatment this time around.

Ironically. O'Rourke would have to go through the Democrats' latest pretender to a throne in Texas. Jasmine Crockett is making her interest in the Senate race known, and the No Kings contingent are already prostrating themselves at her feet. Literally.

For people whose whole thing is ‚Äúno kings‚Äù they sure seem quite eager to have a king pic.twitter.com/1DuluVYCqZ‚Äî Lydia Moynihan (@LJMoynihan) November 12, 2025

I kid you not, I was convinced that was an AI-generated video/photo -- until Miller herself confirmed it:

Why, yes I DID kiss the sneakers of @JasmineForUS and I DO worship the ground she walks on! And she was LOVELY about it! ü§£ pic.twitter.com/cUl4K96dam‚Äî Stephanie Miller (@StephMillerShow) November 9, 2025

But, er ... No Kings, amirite?

No Kings Hollywood memories! #nokings pic.twitter.com/eExAuwXWb3‚Äî Stephanie Miller (@StephMillerShow) October 21, 2025

The Left's mouths say "No Kings," but their knees and their lips say, "Rule me, progressive overlords." They are so desperate to sell a monarchy that they're trying to revive the dissipated Kennedy dynasty. If one considers their current talent, of course, that impulse is understandable -- even while being completely hypocritical. 

Editor‚Äôs Note: Every single day, here at Hot Air, we will stand up and FIGHT, FIGHT, FIGHT against the radical left and deliver the conservative reporting our readers deserve. Sometimes, however, we just point and laugh, and let the radical Left embarrass itself. This is one of those times.

news.author: Ed Morrissey

news.title: Obamacare Didn't Fail ‚Äî It's Working Exactly As Intended
news.text:
Now that we're facing another negotiation on Obamacare subsidies, it's time to remind you that Barack's signature legislation didn't fail. Nothing "went wrong" with it. It's working exactly as designed because its purpose was to crash the private insurance industry and become a political wedge issue. 

WHAT WENT WRONG WITH OBAMACARE?@Avik: "[Obamacare] overcharged healthy people that needed insurance to help fund the cost of insurance for sick people, and overcharged young people... The end result is, if only sicker and older people buy insurance, the price of insurance for‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/GYxBdRxXWa‚Äî The Will Cain Show (@WillCainShow) November 11, 2025

That's why, for example, Democrats demanded a year-long extension on the COVID-era subsidies. For those of you without a calendar in front of you, that would have made the subsidies sunset on the eve of the midterm elections. That's not a coincidence. Democrats absolutely planned to use the subsidies as an election issue. If these subsidies are necessary, and the only thing staving off a "healthcare crisis" ‚Äî as the Democrats keep telling me ‚Äî why would they have a sunset date at all?

For political gain. That's why. 

For now, Republicans seem to have denied them that leverage, and it should stay that way.

But I digress.

As I said, Obamacare is working precisely how Democrats wanted it to, and on two fronts. First, the political wedge issue, and second, as the vehicle by which they'll run us over with socialized medicine.

Avik Roy said, "[Obamacare] overcharged healthy people that needed insurance to help fund the cost of insurance for sick people, and overcharged young people... The end result is, if only sicker and older people buy insurance, the price of insurance for everybody goes through the roof."

That is accurate. But that was also intentional. Despite the fact that Nancy Pelosi said we had to pass the bill to find out what's in it, the framers of the legislation knew exactly what they were doing.

Kamala Harris, who was a few million votes away from the Oval Office, said she would abolish private health insurance in favor of a single-payer system. She's not alone. Other prominent Democrats, including Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren, and Bill de Blasio, are on record as advocating for the elimination of private insurance.

If you want a taste of what government-run healthcare would be like, we've already got it thanks to Obamacare. Increased wait times, exploding costs (because nothing is more expensive than when it's "free"), and bureaucratic control of healthcare decisions that should be between a patient and her doctor. I guess that last provision only applies when the woman wants to kill her unborn child. But it would be much more insidious than that in the era of woke.

Yesterday, I wrote about Do No Harm winning a suit to undo a Biden-era rule that rewarded doctors who implemented "anti-racist" plans for their practices. During my interview with Dr. Goldfarb, we touched briefly on woke changes to things like the kidney transplant list, where racial differences were removed despite the fact that Blacks and Whites have different kidney function. The long story short: these "anti-racist" changes definitely cost White people spots on the transplant list, and probably led to deaths.

Now imagine that policy across the entirety of healthcare. My aunt, who is also White, fell over the weekend and broke her hip. Thankfully, she had surgery on Monday and is on the road to recovery. But what happens in a world of socialized medicine where "anti-racist" policies rule the day? Would she have gotten surgery in a timely manner? Would she have gotten surgery at all? She's older, after all, and retired.

Republicans need to reframe the debate on Obamacare. It's not broken. It didn't "go wrong." It was designed to make private insurance unaffordable. It was meant to create the exact "healthcare crisis" we're experiencing now, so that Democrats could swoop in and promise "free" healthcare via socialized medicine.

That's the message we need to take to voters, and a Republican Congress needs to put forth a bill to repeal Obamacare in full and return free market principles to health insurance. The alternative is costly, both in cash and in lives.
news.author: Amy Curtis

news.title: Sherrod Brown Chances of Beating Jon Husted to Flip Ohio for Democrats‚ÄîPoll
news.text:
Former Democratic Senator Sherrod Brown has improved his chances of winning a Senate seat in Ohio after his 2024 loss, according to a new poll released Tuesday.

Newsweek has reached out to Brown and Husted‚Äôs campaigns for comment via email on Wednesday.

Why It Matters

Brown, who was in office for 18 years, lost last year‚Äôs Senate race to Republican Bernie Moreno. Historically, the party in the White House loses seats in the midterms, but Ohio has grown increasingly conservative over the past decade. The state backed President Donald Trump by double digits in November, which also saw its former senator, JD Vance, to the vice presidency.

Democrats notched wins in gubernatorial races, mayoral contests and a key ballot measure on Tuesday, but redistricting fights, an upcoming Supreme Court ruling and a tougher 2026 U.S. Senate map could temper that momentum heading into the midterms.

Democrats will need to win double-digit Trump seats to win control of the Senate, where Republicans hold a 53-47 majority. Democrats view Maine, which voted for Vice President Kamala Harris by about 7 points, and North Carolina, which voted for Trump by about 3 points, as flip opportunities. But no other GOP-held seats in Harris-won or single-digit Trump states are up for grabs, meaning Democrats have to target more conservative states like Alaska, Iowa, Ohio and Texas.

Democratic Ohio Sen. Sherrod Brown speaks during a watch party on election night, Nov. 5, 2024, in Columbus, Ohio. (AP Photo/Joshua A. Bickel, File)

What To Know

Brown, who served in the Senate from 2007 to 2025, announced his 2026 Senate run in August. He is running against Husted who was appointed by Ohio Governor Mike DeWine to fill Vance‚Äôs seat in January.

Senate doesn‚Äôt elect every member each cycle because senators serve six-year terms. In November 2026, 33 seats will be contested, 20 of which are currently held by Republicans and 13 by Democrats.

A Hart Research poll conducted on behalf of the Ohio Federation of Teachers surveyed 800 likely Ohio voters and found a boost in Brown‚Äôs chances of flipping Husted‚Äôs seat.

The survey, released Tuesday and conducted between September 19 and 22, found that likely voters overall prefer Brown, 48 percent, to Husted, 45 percent. It was conducted ahead of the government shutdown and the 2025 elections.

Brown led independent voters by 25 percentage points, with 56 percent backing him and 31 percent supporting Husted. Both candidates polled well among their own parties, while Brown also performed better among women, 54 percent to 40 percent.

The poll also found that Brown is viewed more favorably overall, with a 42 percent favorability rating, while Husted is viewed favorably by only 21 percent. The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points.

U.S. Sen. Jon Husted, candidate for Senate in 2026, speaks in Columbus, Monday, Sept. 22, 2025. (AP Photo/Sue Ogrocki)

Another poll has found Brown slightly ahead. Conducted by Bowling Green State University, the survey showed Brown with 49 percent and Husted with 48. It surveyed 800 registered voters from October 2-14 and has a margin of error of plus or minus 4.5 percentage points.

An earlier Emerson College poll of 1,000 registered Ohio voters conducted between August 18-19, found Husted ahead of Brown, 50 percent to 44 percent. The poll also found Brown‚Äôs favorability rating higher than Husted‚Äôs, 44 percent to the incumbent‚Äôs 33 percent. The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.

What People Are Saying 

Sherrod Brown said in an X post on November 9: ‚ÄúHalf a million Ohioans are facing monthly premiums that are double or triple what they were paying. This is a bad deal for Ohioans. It does nothing to help the out-of-control costs people are facing. We can‚Äôt allow health care costs to skyrocket and not be willing to fight. This is a problem created by Jon Husted and his special interest friends. At any point over the last 40 days, Jon Husted could have voted to reopen the government and helped people afford health care. But Jon Husted has done nothing to keep health care costs down.‚Äù

Senator Jon Husted said in a November 9 X post: ‚ÄúAfter 40 days of needless suffering for the American people, enough reasonable Democrats did the right thing and voted with us to end the Schumer Shutdown. We now have a path forward to put a stop to the damage of the shutdown and get back to work. I voted for the 15th time to reopen the government and to give hardworking Americans the pay and benefits they depend on. Ohioans can always count on me to be part of the solution.‚Äù

Ohio Federation of Teachers said in a November 12 X post sharing the poll: ‚ÄúOFT Poll: @SherrodBrown is leading Senator Jon Husted by 3 points. Sherrod has double digit leads with independent voters, moderate voters, suburban voters, and women, an...
news.summary: A new poll finds a boost for former Senator Sherrod Brown in his 2026 campaign.

news.title: FBI Arrests California Gov. Gavin Newsom‚Äôs Former Chief Of Staff
news.text:
California Democratic Gov. Gavin Newsom‚Äôs former chief of staff Dana Williamson was arrested Wednesday and charged with conspiracy to commit bank and wire fraud, among other crimes, according to the U.S. Attorney‚Äôs Office for the Eastern District of California.

In a press statement, the office announced that a 23-count indictment was unsealed Wednesday morning following Williamson‚Äôs arrest. A federal grand jury charged her with filing false tax returns, making false statements and participating in conspiracies to commit bank and wire fraud, defraud the United States and obstruct justice.

U.S. Attorney Eric Grant, who announced the arrest, called the charges a ‚Äúcrucial step‚Äù in a three-year political corruption investigation. (RELATED: White House Rips Newsom A New One After ‚ÄòDisrespect‚Äô Comment At Climate Confab)

‚ÄúAs it always has, the U.S. Attorney‚Äôs Office will continue to work tirelessly with our law enforcement partners to protect the people of California from political corruption,‚Äù Grant said.

Between February 2022 and September 2024, Williamson allegedly conspired with others to divert about $225,000 from a dormant political campaign to an associate‚Äôs personal use, according to court documents. Prosecutors claim Williamson and her associates funneled the money through multiple business entities, disguising it as payment for ‚Äúwhat was, in reality, a no-show job.‚Äù

Williamson served as Newsom‚Äòs chief of staff from 2022 to 2024, leaving in December after the governor appointed Nathan Barankin to the role. Reports at the time noted that Newsom chose Barankin for his White House experience under former Vice President Kamala Harris, amid speculation about Newsom‚Äôs political ambitions.

In a statement provided to the Daily Caller News Foundation, a spokesperson for the governor stated Williamson ‚Äúno longer serves in this administration.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhile we are still learning details of the allegations, the Governor expects all public servants to uphold the highest standards of integrity,‚Äù the spokesperson stated. ‚ÄúAt a time when the President is openly calling for his Attorney General to investigate his political enemies, it is especially important to honor the American principle of being innocent until proven guilty in a court of law by a jury of one‚Äôs peers.‚Äù

Officials also allege the 53-year-old political consultant worked with a business associate to create false, backdated contracts after she was subpoenaed in January 2024 by the U.S. Attorney‚Äôs Office over Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) loans tied to her business.

Additionally, Williamson is accused of filing false tax returns, claiming more than $1 million in business deductions for ‚Äúwhat were actually personal and nondeductible expenditures,‚Äù including luxury hotel stays, home furnishings and private jet travel, according to prosecutors.

Williamson is expected to make her first appearance in court Wednesday at 2 p.m. local time.

news.title: Who Is Jack Schlossberg? JFK‚Äôs Grandson And Kennedy Scion Running For Congress In 2026
news.text: Jack Schlossberg, the grandson of former US President John F Kennedy, announced that he will run for Congress in 2026. The 32-year-old said he will seek to represent New York‚Äôs 12th Congressional District, a seat currently held by Rep Jerry Nadler, who announced in September that he will not seek reelection. What‚Äôs Behind The Move? Schlossberg, a Democrat, said his campaign is motivated by the need to address what he called a ‚Äúcost of living crisis‚Äù caused by Republican and Trump administration policies, including Donald Trump‚Äôs ‚ÄúBig Beautiful Bill.‚Äù He said these policies had led to deep cuts in essential services such as health care, education, and child care, hurting working families, as per ABC News report. What Schlossberg Said In his announcement video posted on Instagram, Schlossberg said, ‚ÄúWe deserve better, and we can do better, and it starts with the Democratic Party winning back control of the House of Representatives.‚Äù He said that control of Congress would give Democrats the power to enact meaningful change, warning that without it, ‚Äúwe‚Äôre helpless to a third term.‚Äù Schlossberg, whose full name is John Bouvier Kennedy Schlossberg, is a graduate of Yale University and Harvard Law School. He has previously served as a surrogate speaker for President Joe Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris, and spoke at the Democratic National Convention. news.title: Fetterman Exposes Left's Cruelty, Reveals Problems With Josh Shapiro
news.text:
Sen. John Fetterman (D-PA) doesn't seem shy about saying exactly what he thinks.

He showed that again with the government shutdown, which he chastised his party for causing. He was a "yes" vote to open the government to begin with. 

That earned him a lot of ire from the left. During an interview on CNN with Dana Bash for his book, "Unfettered," Fetterman explained that the "most poisonous, the bitterest" venom he had experienced was from the far left. 

Fetterman said the worst was from Bluesky, the leftist social media haven. 

 And the difference is, I mean, the right would say really rough things and names. You know, some names I won't -- I won't repeat on, on TV. But -- but -- but the -- on the left, it was like they want me to die or we're cheering for your next stroke. Or that's terrible, that depression. Why couldn't the depression have won? And I hope your kids find you.

He said they even had a stroke gif, and said the doctor "let us down...why did they have to save his life?" That shocked even Bash, who was shaking her head at how evil the attacks were. Fetterman said he didn't know where such thinking comes from, but he's made it clear that it wasn't going to stop him from saying what he thinks.

Democrats' Lone Voice of Sanity Admits 'I Should've Quit,' Speaks to Future With Party

He was so ticked off at him, he threatened to run against him for governor in 2022. 

‚ÄúI told him there were two tracks ‚Äî that one and the one in which he ran for governor and I ran for the Senate (which was the one I preferred),‚Äú Fetterman writes in his new book, ‚ÄúUnfettered,‚Äù as excerpted by the Philadelphia Inquirer‚ÄùI had no interest in friction, only in what I felt was justice.‚Äù

He said he thought Shapiro was driven by "political ambition." 

Although their relationship had never recovered, he said he wished Shapiro well. But that didn't stop him from dishing to Kamala Harris about his concerns about Shapiro. 

During the 2024 campaign, Fetterman privately confided his apprehension about Shapiro to former Vice President Kamala Harris‚Äô team as they considered potential running mates, Politico reported at the time.

That might be one of the reasons she didn't pick him, and it gives the questions about Shapiro more credence if Fetterman is also saying it.

news.title: Fetterman torches Democrat Party in new book: 'Elitist,' 'lost touch' with working class
news.text: Botched policies, ignoring reality, and turning their backs on the voters that built the party are the key ingredients that Sen. John Fetterman, D-Pa., believed helped Democrats lose big last year. In his memoir "Unfettered," Fetterman unloaded on the Democratic Party and his colleagues' missteps that he argued led to President Donald Trump's victory over former Vice President Kamala Harris, and a sea change in Washington, D.C. Fetterman argued that the Democratic Party had lost touch with the working class, a key bloc of voters that at one point made up the backbone of the party. DEMOCRATS, LEFT EMPTY-HANDED IN SHUTDOWN, TURN FURY ON SCHUMER In particular, it was the attacks on men, be it through speeches or legislation, that helped turn the Democratic Party into an elitist organization too focused on "celebrity endorsements," he said. In turn, those who voted for Trump perceived "Democrats as soft and gooey, with a platform built on ideals that weren‚Äôt based in the reality of the average person." "We became the party of the elites, one that had lost touch with its base," he wrote. "Also, the continued speech and policies against men have not been without consequences." "If men are forced to choose between picking their party or keeping their balls, most men are going to choose their balls," Fetterman continued. Fetterman‚Äôs book, released on Tuesday, comes at a particular inflection point for Democrats. The party had spent much of the year searching for a binding message to both rebuild their brand with voters and build unity among their ranks in Congress. SENATE ENDS 41-DAY GOVERNMENT SHUTDOWN STALEMATE, SENDS BIPARTISAN DEAL TO HOUSE That came with the government shutdown, where Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., and the majority of the caucus moved in lockstep with demands that the government wouldn't reopen until expiring Obamacare subsidies were dealt with. Schumer‚Äôs failure to prevent a cohort of Senate Democrats, including Fetterman, from crossing the aisle to join Republicans has earned him heat from progressives in the House and outside the walls of Congress. Despite often straying from Schumer‚Äôs position, particularly throughout the shutdown, Fetterman wrote sparingly of the top Senate Democrat. Instead, he is briefly mentioned when reflecting on Schumer‚Äôs 2023 decision to change the dress code on the Senate floor to accommodate Fetterman, whose standard dress is a baggy hoodie and basketball shorts. But Schumer caved on that initiative, too, in early 2024. MIKE JOHNSON EYES WEDNESDAY VOTE WITH END OF GOVERNMENT SHUTDOWN IN SIGHT "Schumer was forced to reverse himself and enforce a dress code aimed at me," Fetterman wrote. One policy area in particular that Fetterman felt Democrats had failed was immigration. He reiterated that while he was pro-immigration, Democrats‚Äô unwillingness to tackle the growing crisis at the southern border under former President Joe Biden was something he couldn‚Äôt get behind. He wrote that Democrats‚Äô assertion that "an open border is a compassionate policy," wasn‚Äôt based in reality. "It is chaos, both for those immigrants and for the citizens impacted by the overwhelming number of people coming in who need assistance," he wrote. CLICK HERE TO DOWNLOAD THE FOX NEWS APP And further, that position likely played a large factor in Trump and the GOP‚Äôs across-the-board victories in 2024, Fetterman argued. "Democrats were swearing up and down that the border was secure and telling its voters to not believe their own eyes," he wrote. "I suspect this may have been the deciding factor in the 2024 election. You can‚Äôt tell people to not believe their own eyes and expect to win elections."
news.summary: In his new memoir, Sen. John Fetterman, D-Pa., blames Democratic Party's disconnect from working-class voters and border policy missteps for President Donald Trump's victory.
news.author: Alex Miller

news.title: 'Not very well': JD Vance's criticism of former Vice President Dick Cheney
news.text:
WASHINGTON ‚Äî Vice President JD Vance took a swipe at former two-term vice president Dick Cheney, a Trump critic who died last week, during a discussion with Robert F. Kennedy Jr. at a MAHA health event about his approach to the job.

Kennedy said Lyndon B. Johnson felt sidelined as vice president by his uncle, former President John F. Kennedy, while Cheney "seemed to be actually running the county" during George W. Bush's administration.

"Not very well, as it turns out," Vance interjected, with a laugh.

To which Kennedy replied: "We agree on that."

Cheney died from complications of pneumonia and cardiac and vascular disease on Nov. 3. He was 84. His funeral will be held on Nov. 20 at the Washington National Cathedral.

The former Wyoming lawmaker, White House chief of staff and defense secretary was the architect of the "war on terror" and defended the Bush administration's interrogation and indefinite detention of terrorism suspects at Guantanamo Bay. He is considered the most powerful vice president in American history.

President Donald Trump has said the Bush administration made a "mistake" in taking the country to war with Iraq. Vance has also criticized the war, which he saw up close in 2005 as a combat correspondent in the Marines.

Trump has not commented on Cheney's death, and the White House suggested last week that it wasn't involved in his funeral arrangements.

"I don't believe the White House is involved in that planning or at least hasn't gotten to it yet. I know the president is aware of the former vice president's passing and, as you saw, flags have been lowered to half-staff in accordance with statutory law," White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said hours after Cheney's family announced his death on Nov. 4.

The former Republican vice president's daughter, former Wyoming Rep. Liz Cheney, is also an outspoken Trump critic. She lost a primary for her House seat to a Trump-backed challenger in 2021 after she voted to impeach the Republican president over the Jan. 6 insurrection at the Capitol.

She and her father endorsed former Vice President Kamala Harris in the 2024 presidential election over Trump.

"He tried to steal the last election using lies and violence to keep himself in power after the voters had rejected him," Dick Cheney said at the time. "He can never be trusted with power again. As citizens, we each have a duty to put country above partisanship to defend our Constitution."

Contributing: Kinsey Crowley
news.author: Usa Today

news.title: Big Chunk Of Trump‚Äôs 2024 Voter Coalition Splits Off In 2025, Potentially Spelling Danger For GOP
news.text:
In one of the more surprising twists of the 2024 election (at least for those liberals and Beltway pundits who could never fathom such a development), President Donald Trump swung a massive number of Latinos into the fold of the GOP.

For a Republican candidate, Trump won 48% of Latino voters, compared to 36% in 2020 and 28% in 2016, according to data the Pew Research Center released in June. Former Vice President Kamala Harris only managed to win Latino voters, typically a solid, reliable voting bloc for Democrats, by a mere 3% in November 2024. Despite the historic swing, the 2025 election results spell trouble for Republicans as they seek to keep this coalition intact for the midterms in 2026. (Subscribe to MR. Enten went on to explain that data shows that during the run-up to the 2024 presidential election, more Americans trusted that Trump was more capable of fixing ‚Äúthe problem of inflation‚Äù than his opponent, former Vice President Kamala Harris. 

A year later, however, it seems that most voters feel like Trump sold them nothing more than a bunch of useless snake oil when it comes to his economic policies. 

‚ÄúLook at where we are today. Donald Trump is underwater with the Titanic when it comes to inflation,‚Äù Enten said, noting that the president‚Äôs net approval rating is now 26 points in the negative. 

‚ÄúMy goodness gracious,‚Äù Enten said about Trump‚Äôs plummeting numbers.

Watch the video below:

Enten went on to point out that Trump‚Äôs go-to tactic of passing ‚Äúthe political buck‚Äù when ‚Äúthings aren‚Äôt going his way‚Äù isn‚Äôt going to fly this time, especially if he‚Äôs placing the blame on his predecessor, former President Joe Biden.

‚ÄúThat, simply put, will not work,‚Äù Enten said, pointing to data sourced from ‚Äúpoll after poll after poll‚Äù that indicated that 54% of voters believe that Trump is more responsible for their financial woes, compared to the 21% who blame Biden.

‚ÄúNow, of course, it‚Äôs one thing if voters don‚Äôt like the state of the economy,‚Äù Enten said. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs another thing when they don‚Äôt think that Donald Trump actually gives a hoot.‚Äù

He then pulled up data that showed that 75% of voters feel that Trump is ‚Äúnot paying enough attention to lowering costs‚Äù ‚Äî and that this opinion is held by 57% of Republicans.

Enten said that the GOP ‚Äúshould be scared s-h-blank-blank-blank-less‚Äù over Trump‚Äôs let-them-eat-cake vibes, because voters are clearly ticked off. Enten pointed to Democrats‚Äô big wins in local elections earlier this month, and noted that midterm elections are in a year.

‚ÄúIf these numbers hold and Donald Trump continues to try [to] ignore a problem that Americans very much think we have in terms of cost of living, affordability, well, it might be adios, amigos.‚Äù 

‚ÄúGoodbye for that House majority, and I daresay, the Republican Senate majority as well,‚Äù Enten said.

Funny enough, not-so-dumb actor Jeff Daniels made a similar call earlier this year when he told MSNBC host Nicolle Wallace in July that he hopes Trump voters are ‚Äúlosing tons of money.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think, at the end of the day, that‚Äôs what‚Äôs going to do it,‚Äù the Emmy-winner said of Trump supporters turning on the president because of money. ‚Äú‚ÄòWait a minute, the grocery bill is what, $180 more? I can‚Äôt get that car that we have to have unless I pay another $8,000. What? Who do I blame for that? Who do I see about that?‚Äô One person.‚Äù
news.author: Elyse Wanshel
